fields.name: Alphabet Flat White
fields.description: Greater Manchester is home to a boatload of amazing breweries, and Alphabet are one of the forerunners. Their Flat White is, aptly enough, a white variant of a breakfast stout. Expect the usual oaty, coffee flavours of your regular breakfast stout, but with a particularly milky flavour that sets it apart from the pack.

fields.name: Vocation Pure Pilsner
fields.description: Vocation have been hitting the Pilsners hard recently and to great success. Pure Pilsner is their classic variant. At 4.2%, it’s sessionable and it pours a wonderful clear gold. To taste, it’s every bit the classic pilsner: clean, crisp and with the signature bitter bite that every true pilsner should come with. There’s hay, a light spice and bready malts rounding off what is a perfect example of a classic style. Well done Vocation!

fields.name: Thornbridge Jaipur
fields.description: Jaipur the Thornbridge star! This beer has won so many awards it can't stand up straight! A really wonderful hoppiness leaves you wanting more and that, combined with a none too subtle 5.9% ABV, has led to the phrase 'I'm just a bit jaipured' becoming a real phrase in some parts! Tropical fruits and grassy tastes abound if you don't drink at fridge temperature.

fields.name: Brewgooder Clean Water Lager
fields.description: How often do you drink a beer that genuinely does good in the world? That’s exactly what Brewgooder does - 100% of their profits go to providing clean water to communities that need it around the world. So not only are you helping those in need, but you also get to enjoy a ruddy good lager - brewed with Sorachi Ace and Saaz hops - at the same time. This really is a good beer!

fields.name: Harviestoun Bitter & Twisted
fields.description: Famed for the great but more common Bitter and Twisted and Schiehallion, we believe Harviestoun's best beers are their darker Porters and Stouts. It's either in the pure Scottish water of the Ochi hills or something in the Scottish Malts, either way we love 'em. Their icon and mascot is a fractious mouse which appears on each of the labels and was apparently the inspiration for the first brew. Bitter and Twisted is a classic English golden ale--and a former Champion Beer of Britain--with a superb hop profile of Hersbrucker, Challenger, and Styrian Goldings. Spicy, zesty, bitter and with a twist of lemon, this delicately carbonated ale finishes clean and dry. It's quite refreshing!

fields.name: Black Sheep My Generation
fields.description: We’re going to put it out there and say hard candy on the nose, call us crazy. Pour is slightly hazy and is pale yellow in colour. Taste is quite sweet, with a little orange and bread and a delicately bitter finish.

fields.name: Black Sheep Pathmaker
fields.description: The self-proclaimed guardians of The North created this little number in tribute to their founder Paul Theakston. The ‘hipster’ illustration certainly took us by surprise, it’s good to see them endeavour to keep up with the modern beer drinker. Grapefruit on the nose of this hazy yellow brew. Sweet malt character and a surprising tropical element, we recommend you crack this open for BBQs, nativity plays, christenings and any other occasion.

fields.name: Berliner Pilsner
fields.description: The bear on the can is a reference to the Berlin coat of arms, fun fact! A perfectly clear golden pour with a generous white head. Roasted malt and hay on the nose, slight caramel malt taste and a crisp clean finish. An excellent example of a pilsner, Prost!

fields.name: Hoegaarden
fields.description: Even in Belgium before the 1960s, you’d have struggled to find a witbier. That is, until Pierre Celis resurrected this style of wheat beer – once widely brewed – in the town of Hoegaarden. Celis revived the style adding coriander seeds and Curaçao orange peel to make one of the world’s most refreshing styles. Today, Hoegaarden is the world’s most popular witbier and drank around the world.

fields.name: Goose Island Midway
fields.description: Goose Island were one of the early titans of the American craft scene and they have churned out great beer after great beer. Midway is Goose’s offering for those who love big American IPAs but perhaps want to dial down the ABV a bit. It packs all the flavour into a lower ABV format commendably. It’s got the big pine and resin licks and a solid biscuit base that will have you coming back for more at the beginning, Midway through and at the end of a good ol’ session.

fields.name: Union Sunday Pale Ale
fields.description: Brewers & Union work with both German and Belgian brewers to develop a fantastically rich range of artisan beer. All are unfiltered so have a lovely full texture and flavour. While angered by the monotonous flavours so widely available in lager, they have a wonderfully realistic philosophy 'We don't believe we can single-handedly change the world of beer, but with a little raw passion, blind optimism and reckless resolve, we can perhaps make a difference. And Union works with small Bavarian breweries to produce modern, flavoursome beer which is unfiltered and unpasteurised. This is an easy drinking pale ale with notes of soft citrus fruit and freshly cut grass, balanced by toffee and biscuit with a lightly resinous finish.

fields.name: Yeastie Boys Big Mouth
fields.description: Yeastie Boys is part of the New Zealand Beer Collective that is taking the country by storm with the lively beers out of the country. Big Mouth is a session IPA rolling in at 4.4%, full of trademark South Pacific hops that give a mesmeric tropical taste. Despite being in the middle of January, sip this and be transported to summer.

fields.name: Flying Dog Snake Dog
fields.description: Flying Dog Brewery Gonzo journalist and long time friend of Flying Dog owner George Stranahan, Hunter S Thompson was a large influence on the creation of Flying Dog brand. The unique labels and branding are the work of artist co-conspirator Ralph Steadman. This American IPA from Flying Dog is 60 IBUs of goodness! Packed full of Warrior and Columbus hops, Snake Dog's grapefruit, resinous pine and caramel flavours give way to a long, lingering bitterness which will delight any hop lover. At a robust 7.1% it's a great match for spicy food, but is equally enjoyable to drink on its own when you fancy something big and bitter.

fields.name: The White Hag Little Fawn
fields.description: With sharp citrus and tropical fruit flavours throughout, this 4.2% ABV session IPA from The White Hag is dry and refreshing. Little Fawn has a balanced bitter character, accompanied by prominent notes of pineapple, lemon peel and light biscuit malts.

fields.name: Amundsen Run To The Pils
fields.description: Run to the Pils, Run for your life!!! At Beer Hawk we have a lot of time for beer based puns; our Norwegian chums at Amundsen have treated us to their bizarre, yet wonderful interpretation of a classic Pilsner beer. By appearance, everything seems relatively normal. But the sharp smell of fresh lemon grass along with the piney aroma of American Hops quickly lets you know that there are deeper things at work here. The citrus and pine join in a marvellous team up, providing a level of refreshment you won’t be ready for.

fields.name: Firestone Walker Easy Jack
fields.description: Packing a load of flavour into 4.5% ABV, Firestone Walker's Easy Jack is a Session IPA that features hop varieties from Germany, New Zealand and North America. Predictably, the hops are prominent with flavours of pineapple, mango, peach and grapefruit yet its classic malt profile provides a fantastic balance. Medium-bodied, moderately carbonated and bitter for ages, it's EASY (see what we did there?) to love this beer.

fields.name: Omnipollo Mazarin
fields.description: A pale ale from legendary Swedish brewers Omnipollo, Maz is a delight to drink. Pouring cloudy, amber with a beautiful, fluffy white head. The aroma blasts citrus in your face, with lime, orange and grapefruit all in evidence. A taste starts sweet and fruity, with grapefruit and spices the dominant flavours . It finishes medium bitter and will have your coming back again and again and again. Omnipollo knock it out of the park on this one!

fields.name: Moor Stout
fields.description: This is a wonderfully smooth stout from Moor. A medium body with all the right flavours, toasted malt, chocolate, molasses, coffee. Some wonderful sweet qualities, a little toffee and caramel thrown in for good measure. This is all beautifully balanced with slightly bitter coffee notes. Well rounded and thoroughly enjoyable.

fields.name: Mondo Brewing ALL CAPS
fields.description: The All Caps Pilsner is one of Mondo Brewing Company's core range beers. Focusing on drinkability as opposed to massive flavours, this classic American-style lager doesn't rely on dry-hopping or smoke machines to make it interesting. Noble hop aromas are mirrored on the palate alongside a corn-grain sweetness with notes of hay, a bit of orange and a solid bitterness. A light body, creamy mouthfeel and a crisp, dry finish won't have you screaming in ALL CAPS but you'll finish this thinking you just had a really nice beer.

fields.name: Yeastie Boys White Noise
fields.description: A quaffable, cloudy white ale that is perfect for those afternoon sessions after a hard day's work or play. Pours a cloudy pale straw colour with a dense mousse-like white head. A perfumy coconut and vanilla note on the nose, with a little citrus and spice, and bready grains from the wheat. The mouthfeel is full for such a pale beer, but still very light and elegant. The beer finishes with a cleansing acidity, a faint spicy note and only the mildest touch of citrus from the virtually non-existent hops.

fields.name: Williams Bros. Joker
fields.description: Laughing madly, the Joker will caper through your beery gathering, sprinkling mischief and mirth wherever it goes. Joker IPA is a classic IPA with a few modern twists. It's lightly hopped with American hops giving it a tasty citrus tang, and it's backed up with a solid malty base and some pleasing grassy and earthy overtones. Perfect for a party, this beer is crowd-pleaser which will keep everybody, old and young happy and jolly.

fields.name: Amundsen Dessert In A Can Choco Marshmellow
fields.description: Liquid chocolate cake? Errr yes please Amundsen!!!! The moment you pour this beautiful beer, the first thing you notice is that the texture is thick and unctuous, rolling it’s way around the glass and you know you’re in for a treat of a lifetime. The aroma is akin to the richest chocolate fondant and the mouthfeel is silky smooth. Flavours jump from sticky toffee and chocolate milkshake in a heartbeat, and you’d almost be tempted to have a scoop of vanilla ice cream on the side. Amundsen were not lying – this really is a desert in a can. Unless you read the side of the can, you’d be forgiven for having no idea that this beer rocks in at 10.5%! Go on… See the desert menu….
